alert.note: Alert for Greenville (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 05 at 8:44AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 445 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Portions of western North Carolina and Upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, in western North Carolina, Buncombe, Henderson, Polk and Rutherford. In Upstate South Carolina, Greenville and Spartanburg. * WHEN...Until 445 PM EDT Monday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 839 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rainfall due to persistent, repeating rain showers. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen, and additional rainfall of 1 to 2 inches is expected through early this afternoon, which may worsen flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hendersonville, Columbus, Flat Rock, Landrum, Slater- Marietta, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Tryon, Lake Lure, Saluda, Chimney Rock Village, Chimney Rock State Park, Bat Cave, Tigerville, Pleasant Ridge State Park, Jones Gap State Park, Dupont State Forest, Valley Hill, Dana and Lake Adger. Flooding is most likely along Mud Creek in Henderson County, tributaries to the North Saluda River in Greenville County, and Buffalo Creek in Rutherford County. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
